Hey JB,

The primary goal of Agile Java is to give [ new programmers | non-java 
programmers | non-TDD practitioners ] a technique for learning how to 
construct quality Java systems. I've found TDD to be a good teaching 
tool in itself. The book introduces OO design concepts throughout (not 
in a heavy-handed fashion, however), my attempt to make a more seamless 
learning experience.

Most programmers learn Java separately from OO concepts. Most Java 
books, sadly, teach it largely from a syntactical standpoint. Few books 
do a good job of both. Same with TDD--new programmers learn Java's 
syntax of, then come back and have to rethink how to construct their 
code. Seems wasteful to me. I see the pain constantly from old dogs 
(like myself)--it's a real struggle to change your approach to 
developing software after so many years of ingraining code construction 
techniques.

Agile Java still uses JUnit 3.8 (it was written mostly in 2004, and 
first appeared in Feb 2005), but (a) JUnit 4 is a reasonably easy 
transition, (b) most programmers will need and want to know both for a 
while yet, and (c) the tool ain't the thing--I'd also like to think that 
someone could quickly adapt the code in the book to TestNG. Agile Java 
hasn't sold gobs of copies, although it got some very good reviews. I 
think that's because it was at least a year ahead of Java 5 starting to 
take off, which it seems to have finally been starting to do this year.

One thing I'm pretty proud of is how the book is crafted to introduce as 
few "forward references" as possible, and how it emphasizes OO 
development over procedural. I don't talk about arrays ([]) until pretty 
far into the book.

JB, your best strategy is to probably buy a few thousand copies. That 
way no one will know if you ended up rewriting it.

I think there's a market for an "agile ruby..."

Jeff
